etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Promptorium Parvulorum. From early Scandinavian (compare Old Icelandic gólf floor, bay in a building, Old Swedish golf floor (Swedish golv floor, bay in a building), Old Danish gulv floor, bay in a building (Danish gulv floor, (regional) room, bay of a barn, barn)), further etymology uncertain

definitions: A rick or stack of corn, straw, etc., in a barn. Also: the quantity of corn, straw, etc., stacked up and stored in one bay or division of a barn. Compare "hay-goaf", "mow". English regional (chiefly East Anglian) in later use.
"to ride the goaf": to ride a horse on top of a goaf in order to compress it and make it more compact. Now chiefly historical.

etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in The Edinburgh Encyclopaedia. Origin unknown

definitions: An empty space from which coal has been extracted in a longwall mine, sometimes filled with waste material.
